Founded as Germany's first seaside resort in 1793 by Duke Friedrich Franz I of Mecklenburg-Schwerin, Heiligendamm was once the favored retreat for Europe's noble and elite classes, who were drawn to its blond dunes, wide blue skies and snow-white manors. But that changed after World War II, when the elegant bleached facades faded to gray. Grand lodgings once used by vacationing German kaisers and Russian czars became a sanatorium for Socialist workers.

The recent turnaround was led by the Kempinski Grand Hotel Heiligendamm (49-38203-7400; www.kempinski-heiligendamm.de), which converted six buildings including the Kurhaus, the duke's original house, into a glittering seaside campus. Opened in 2003, the resort has a 32,000-square-foot spa, a chandeliered ballroom, high-end restaurants and 225 rooms starting at 195 to 295 euros ($267 to $404 at $1.37 to the euro) a night, depending on the season.

The wedding cake-like resort has become a haunt of celebrities like the fashion designer Wolfgang Joop, the supermodel Nadja Auermann and members of the German national soccer team, as well as less celebrated people. ''We get a lot of young families, or people who come for a weekend from Hamburg or Berlin,'' said Hannelore Neubert, a waitress at the hotel's Baltic Bar.
Then there was President George W. Bush, who stayed at the Kempinski last July during a 36-hour diplomatic visit to meet with Chancellor Angela Merkel.

''My kids still talk about 'Georgie,' who went biking without his bodyguards last year,'' said Birgit Koch, who operates a small guesthouse nearby, Gästehaus Koch (Gartenstrasse 1a; 49-38203-63882; www.urlaub-in-heiligendamm.de).

Heiligendamm isn't just high thread counts and white-gloved concierges. A quiet, natural beauty envelops the town. Sandy beaches extend for miles. Hiking trails crisscross the beech woodlands. And there are lush rolling fields, which visitors can view from the Molli, a vintage train that chugs through fairy-tale forests.

Farther inland is a freshwater lake, the Conventer Niederung, which draws spagoers and rehab patients to its peat mud, long reputed to have curative properties. Twenty-minute heated mud baths at the Moorbad Bad Doberan (Schwaaner Chaussee 2, Bad Doberan; 49-38203-930; www .moorbad-doberan.de), an old bathhouse that relocated to a modern clinic in 1996, start at 36 euros; weeklong retreats are 735 euros.
''The landscape is lovely, the air is good, and this area just brims with history,'' said Rainer Grimm, its director.

There are other signs that Heiligendamm is regaining its glory. A historic horse racing track, Ostsee-Rennbahn (www.ostseerennbahn.de), was once consigned to landfill status. Now there are V.I.P.'s in fancy hats and long gloves sipping Champagne in the summer. And a string of derelict seaside villas near the Kempinski is slated to become regal summer homes and luxury shops.

''I knew this place when it was falling apart,'' said Frauke Müller, the public relations manager at the Kempinski, which will play host to the G-8 heads of state and their entourages during the summit. ''The whole region's in transformation.''
